instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> short
threads.message: I have this card going on 20v but with 0.001A I discovered a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> lifting <CHIP>U8295</CHIP>, mo I can't find the component in short how many Volts should I use to find it ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
What is the exact ohm value of that short?
Did you remove <CHIP>U8295</CHIP>?

There are many chips connected.
Any history available?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> short
threads.message: I removed the chip because it overheated a lot and then I noticed the short on the feet corresponding to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> and it's 0.002 the value to the ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
Then may have luck with volyage injection.
Start with 2V, no more than 3.5-4V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
I took a look at the schematic, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> becomes
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R5640</RESISTOR> so <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> is most likely gone. could you advise me on a way to not tear the pads when I go to clean the pond under <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> thanks in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> short
threads.message: You should search videos on Internet and practice on scrap boards...
